questions.text: A 45 year old female present with lesion on tongue she was diagnosed as case of tongue carcinoma. Recurrence is suspected and she underwent an MRI . Contrast used in MRI is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gadolinium Contrast used in MRI-Gadolinium DTPA Gadolinium is a lanthanide Gd DTPA is classed as an acyclic, ionic gadolinium contrast medium, its paramagnetic property reduces the TI relaxation time

Highyeild:

Gadolinium contrast media (sometimes called a MRI contrast media, agents or 'dyes') are chemical substances used in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans . When injected into the body, gadolinium contrast medium enhances and improves the quality of the MRI images (or pictures

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - OPTION A,C,D are not used in MRI

Extraedge:

MRI contrast agents are contrast agents used to improve the visibility of internal body structures in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). The most commonly used compounds for contrast enhancement are gadolinium-based contrast agents (GBCAs). Such MRI contrast agents shorten the relaxation times of nuclei within body tissues following oral or intravenous administration.

questions.text: A 54 year old male was planned for coronary angiography after presenting with chest pain and ECG showed st elevation with trop-t positive. For coronary angiography, he was given iodinated low osmolar contrast media. Which of the following in the given options represents the low osmolar iodinated contrast media.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Iohexol In the given question, as asked the low osmolar contrast media from the given option is iohexol.

Highyeild:

Iohexol, sold under the trade name Omnipaque among others, is a contrast agent used for X-ray imaging. This includes when visualizing arteries, veins, ventricles of the brain, the urinary system, and joints, as well as during computed tomography (CT scan).It is given by mouth, injection into a vein, or into a body cavity

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. urograffin- it is an ionic iodinated high ismolar contrast media. Option: B. Iothalamate- it is an ionic iodinated high osmolar contrast media. Option: D. iodixanol- it is iso-osmolar non ionic contrast media.

Extraedge:

Side effects include vomiting, skin flushing, headache, itchiness, kidney problems, and low blood pressure. Less commonly allergic reactions or seizures may occur. Allergies to povidone-iodine or shellfish do not affect the risk of side effects more than other allergies. Use in the later part of pregnancy may cause hypothyroidism in the baby. Iohexol is an iodinated non-ionic radiocontrast agent. It is in the low osmolar family.

questions.text: A 50 year old female undergone CECT for with previous s. creatinine level- 0.7mg/dl. After 2 days, the RFT was again measured which shows s.creatinine to be 1.4mg /dl. What could have been done to prevent the following complication?

options.label: A
options.text: Hydrate the patient with iv saline 0.9% at a rate of 100 ml/hr 12 hour before the procedure.

options.label: B
options.text: Hydrate the patient with iv saline 0.9% at a rate of 50 ml/hr 6 hour before and after the procedure.

options.label: C
options.text: Hydrate the patient with iv saline 0.9% at a rate of 100 ml/hr 12 hours before and after the procedure.

options.label: D
options.text: Mannitol and diuretic can should be used.

questions.correct_answer: C. Hydrate the patient with iv saline 0.9% at a rate of 100 ml/hr 12 hours before and after the procedure.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hydrate the patient with iv saline 0.9% at a rate of 100 ml/hr 12 hours before and after the procedure. In the given question, the clinical diagnosis of the patient will be contrast induced nephropathy, as the s. creatinine has increased from >0.5 mg/dl after 48 hour. To prevent this, adequate hydration should be maintained by- iv saline 0.9% at a rate of 100 ml/hr 12 hours before and after the procedure.

Highyeild:

Contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) is defined as the impairment of kidney function—measured as either a 25% increase in serum creatinine (SCr) from baseline or a 0.5 mg/dL (44 µmol/L) increase in absolute SCr value—within 48-72 hours after intravenous contrast administration.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. and B are not the adequate quantity of hydration to be done. Option: D. Mannitol and diuretics are not effective.

Extraedge:

Gadolinium should probably not be used in patients with chronic kidney disease because of the risk of nephrogenic systemic fibrosis (NSF).

questions.text: You are posted in cardiology during your medicine PG rotation. During angiography of a patient, iodixanol was used which of the following category does this contrast belong to?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Non-ionic dimeric contrast. The iodinated water soluble contrast is divided into two categories as- ionic and non-ionic both of which further have two sub- categories i.e. monomer and dimer. Iodixanol belongs to the non ionic dimer class . Hence the correct answer for this question is option A.

Highyeild:

Iodinated contrast media are contrast agents that contain iodine atoms used for x-ray-based imaging modalities such as computed tomography (CT). They can also be used in fluoroscopy, angiography and venography, and even occasionally, plain radiography.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Ionic monomer contrast- it includes urograffin, gastrograffin. Option: C. Ionic dimer contrast- includes ioxaglate. Option: D. Non-ionic monomer contrast- Includes iohexol.

Extraedge:

Iodinated low osmolar contrast media are currently the standard for angiography. Iso-osmolar contrast such as iodixanol has been shown to be less nephrotoxic than other nonionic low osmolar contrast agents

questions.text: A 41 year old male underwent the following investigation. He was administered iohexol for the same. What can be the reason to use iohexol rather than any other ionic dye?

options.label: A
options.text: Iohexol is used as it will be excreted through kidney.

options.label: B
options.text: To decrease the risk of allergic reaction.

options.label: C
options.text: To decrease the risk of arachnoiditis.

questions.correct_answer: C. To decrease the risk of arachnoiditis.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

To decrease the risk of arachnoiditis. In the given question, the image depicts the investigation- myelography. For myelography, non-ionic dye are used mainly because of the risk of arachnoiditis with other dyes.

Highyeild:

Iodinated contrast media are contrast agents that contain iodine atoms used for x-ray-based imaging modalities such as computed tomography (CT). They can also used in fluoroscopy, angiography and venography, and even occasionally, plain radiography. Although the intravenous route of administration is most common, they are also administered by many other routes, including gastrointestinal (oral, rectal), cystourethral, vaginal, intraosseous, etc.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Iohexol is used as it will be excreted through the kidney. Is not the reason as in this case using any dye won’t be excreted through the kidney still we can't use ionic dye due to risk of arachnoiditis. Option: B. To decrease the risk of allergic reaction - Though non ionic dye reduces the risk of allergic reaction but it is not the important reason here for being used.

Extraedge:

Contraindications Absolute documented previous severe reaction to iodinated contrast media, including anaphylaxis, angioedema and bronchospasm Relative milder previous reactions to iodinated contrast media/excipients renal impairment/failure risk factors for adverse reactions to iodinated contrast media myasthenia gravis: caution is advised, as reports suggest a clear risk of exacerbation of respiratory symptoms

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with recurrent urinary tract infection (UTI) episodes was scheduled for an IVP (intravenous pyelogram). A RFT (renal function test) was done which revealed the serum creatinine (S.Cr.) to be 1.4 mg/dL. Which type of contrast dye should be used in this patient for the IVP?

options.label: D
options.text: Any dye can be used as creatinine is under normal limits.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Non ionic dimer dye. In the given question, the child has mild renal abnormality as the s.creatinine is 1.4mg/dl (1.2-2.5 mg/dl) .For this person, the best option will be to use non-ionic dimer dye like iodixanol.

Highyeild:

Low osmolality contrast media Low osmolality contrast media (LOCM) are less than three times the osmolality of human serum and preferred for intravascular and intrathecal administration. Modern LOCM are generally, but not always, nonionic monomers composed of tri-iodinated benzene rings with various side chains that contain polar alcohol (-OH) groups that make them water-soluble 3 . LOCM in current use include the following: iopamidol (Isovue) iohexol (Omnipaque) iopromide (Ultravist) ioversol (Optiray) ioxilan (Oxilan)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Ionic dye whether dimer or monomer should be used if there is no renal excretion of the dye. Option: B. Non-ionic monomer - they can be used for people with normal RFT. Hence , it should not be used in this patient. Option: D. Any dye can be used as RFT is normal is a wrong statement as RFT is not normal.

Extraedge:

Allergic-like reactions to iodinated contrast agents are rare, accounting for 0.6% of cases with only 0.04% considered severe 9. Patients who suffer from allergic reactions to shellfish or topical iodine are not at any higher risk of contrast allergy than patients with any other allergy or asthma, which is only slightly elevated

questions.text: You are posted in radiology for your internship rotation. You come across 4 different patients on a day for whom certain investigations were to be done. For which of the following patients do we need to do RFT?

options.label: A
options.text: A 22 year old male undergoing CT-angio for pulmonary embolism.

options.label: B
options.text: A 2 month old baby undergoing micturition cystography for posterior urethral valve.

options.label: C
options.text: A 25 year old male with H/O straddle injury with blood at the tip of meatus undergoing RGU.

options.label: D
options.text: A 25 year old female with complaint of infertility undergoing HSG to check for uterine malformation.

questions.correct_answer: A. A 22 year old male undergoing CT-angio for pulmonary embolism.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A 22 year old male undergoing CT-angio for pulmonary embolism. In the given clinical scenarios, we need to apply a simple concept of whether the dye is going to excrete from the kidney or not. In case a dye is given IV or IA then it will definitely excrete from the kidney and hence we need to do RFT. From the above given options, only For patient In A needs RFT measurement.

Highyeild:

Computed tomography angiography (also called CT angiography or CTA) is a computed tomography technique used for angiography—the visualization of arteries and veins—throughout the human body. Using contrast injected into the blood vessels, images are created to look for blockages, aneurysms (dilations of walls), dissections (tearing of walls), and stenosis (narrowing of vessel). CTA can be used to visualize the vessels of the heart, the aorta and other large blood vessels, the lungs, the kidneys, the head and neck, and the arms and legs. CTA can also be used to localise arterial or venous bleed of the gastrointestinal system

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. for patients undergoing MCU for posterior urethral valve , no need to measure RFT. Option: C. A patient undergoing RGU for ruling out urethral injury due to trauma does not need RFT measurement as it will not pass through kidney tubules. Option: D. Similarly, for the female undergoing HSG the dye will not excrete through the kidney. Hence, no need to measure RFT.

Extraedge:

CT pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) is used to examine the pulmonary arteries in the lungs, most commonly to rule out pulmonary embolism (PE), a serious but treatable condition. It has become the technique of choice for detection of pulmonary embolism due to its wide availability, short exam time, ability to see other diseases that may present like pulmonary embolisms, and a high degree of confidence in the validity of the test. In this test, a PE will appear as a dark spot inside the blood vessel or a sudden stop of the bright contrast material

questions.text: 34 year old male who presented to emergency after road traffic accident was having fracture shaft of femur. He was resuscitated and given primary care for the fracture before definitive management. 1 week after the incident, he developed sign and symptoms suggesting of DVT followed by pulmonary embolism for which he underwent CT angiography. Just few minutes after the administration of the dye, he developed breathlessness, choking sensation , edema of the lip. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the following condition?

options.label: A
options.text: It is known as anaphylactic reaction.

options.label: B
options.text: Treatment is iv adrenaline for severe reactions in the ratio of 1:10,000.

options.label: D
options.text: Treatment is adrenaline IM/deep SC in 1:1000 dilution.

questions.correct_answer: A. It is known as anaphylactic reaction.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It is known as anaphylactic reaction. In the given question, the clinical symptoms in the patient are suggestive of anaphylactoid reaction, which is the most common side effect of the iodinated contrast. Hence option A is incorrect as it is not anaphylactic reaction, but anaphylactoid reaction.<="" b="">

Highyeild:

Anaphylactic-type reactions to iodinated contrast agents are rare, accounting for 0.6% of cases with only 0.04% considered aggressive. Almost all contrast reactions that are life-threatening occur within 20 minutes of intravenous injection

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Treatment is iv adrenaline for severe reactions in the ratio of 1:10,000- Is a true statement as for severe reaction even iv adrenaline can also be given in 1:10,000 dilution Option: C. It is complement mediated reaction- is also a correct statement as it is an anaphylactoid reaction which is non- IgE mediated. Option: D. Treatment is adrenaline IM/deep SC in 1:1000 dilution is also a correct statement.

Extraedge:

Prophylaxis with antihistamines and change of the iodinated contrast material used can both reduce the occurrence of a recurrent hypersensitivity reaction 8. A typical premedication regimen for adults includes prednisolone 50 mg orally 13 hours prior and again 1 hour prior 1. Oral corticosteroid therapy should begin at least 6 hours prior to administration of contrast media. Oral non-sedating antihistamines may also be added in addition to the corticosteroid regimen. Local departmental protocols should be adhered to.

questions.text: A 27 year old male present with inability to pass stools as well as flatus, nausea and vomiting. On P/A examination, abdomen looked distended with bowel sounds heard. Abdominal x ray done shows multiple air-fluid level with level of obstruction in supine xray film. If we have to do contrast study in this patient , which of the following agent will be most suitable?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gastro-graffin In the given question, the patient's clinical presentation denotes it to be a case of intestinal obstruction. Hence in case of obstruction, the contrast agent that should not be used is barium sulphate as due to stasis the water will be observed from the dye and barium will form stones and obstruction will be exaggerated. Hence, gastrograffin will be an useful option in this patient. So the correct answer is option B.

Highyeild:

Gastrografin administration is effective in early resolution of obstruction, avoidance of surgery and in turn, a shorter hospital stay . So it has a definite role in the management of intestinal obstruction. Intestinal obstruction is complete or partial blockage of intestinal tract.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Barium sulphate - In case of obstruction, the contrast agent that should not be used is barium sulphate Option: C. Iohexol - NOT preferred in case of obstruction

Extraedge:

A water-soluble contrast challenge (more widely known as a Gastrografin challenge ) is a combined diagnostic study and therapeutic intervention utilized in the evaluation and management of small bowel obstruction. It is used when clinical or imaging features determine there to be small bowel obstruction due to adhesions, without any complications such as perforation or a closed-loop configuration.

questions.text: A 49 year old male after having RTA with Aortic injury wall stable and maintained by iv fluids and primary management was done. He was taken for CT-angio for further management as vitally he was stable. During the CT-angio, he was given ionic contrast agent even when his RFT was not done. He later also reveals the history of having chronic kidney disease. Which of the following factors in the given question can be responsible for development of CIN?

options.label: C
options.text: Ionic contrast, CKD, excretion of contrast through kidney.

questions.correct_answer: C. Ionic contrast, CKD, excretion of contrast through kidney.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ionic contrast, CKD, excretion of contrast through kidney. In the given question, as given the patient is a known case of CKD and above that he was given iodinated contrast without doing RFT , so this increases the risk of CIN.

Highyeild:

The factors responsible for development of CIN are- 1 Excretion through kidney. 2 Pre-existing renal disease. 3 High osmolarity of the contrast agent like with iodinated contrast agent. Hence option C is the correct answer.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. -RTA is not responsible for the development of CIN . Hence, option A is not correct. Option: B. - option B is also correct but option C is more complete and appropriate answer write single choice question type.

Extraedge:

Contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) is defined as the impairment of kidney function—measured as either a 25% increase in serum creatinine (SCr) from baseline or a 0.5 mg/dL (44 µmol/L) increase in absolute SCr value—within 48-72 hours after intravenous contrast administration.

questions.text: During attending your radiology posting in 6th semester of MBBS, you observed contrast study like barium swallow, barium meal being done except for a few cases where barium is contraindicated. Which of the following are the situations in which barium is C/I?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above. In the given question, the contraindication for barium sulphate are asked indirectly

Highyeild:

Hence, barium should not be used in patients with- 1. Patient with small bowel obstruction 2. Patient with trachea-oesophageal fistula 3. Patient with suspected intestinal perforation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Contraindication for barium sulphate are OPTION A, B, C Hence, the correct answer will be option D. all of the above.

Extraedge:

due to obstruction there may be stasis of barium sulphate which attracts water over the course of time and also results in stone
